abstract.para: The following document provides an overview of &sls; JeOS and describes the setup procedure.

sect1.title: Introduction
sect1.para: &jeos; (Just enough Operating System) refers to a minimal customizable operating system that specifically tailored for a specific usage scenario (for example, a container host, a virtual machine guest, an appliance base, or a small server image) The purpose of &jeos; is to make the system as small as possible, while providing the option of installing additional software. This allows you to tailor systems for use in a data center, or create desired virtual application images or appliances. You can choose what packages and components to install based on a specific use case. To that end, &jeos; provides access to all regular software repositories.

If you have &sls; certification, you are automatically certified for &jeos;, as it is derived from the same code base. &sls; &jeos; allows you to reduce the operating system to the packages essential for the specific usage scenario. This minimizes the number of packages and patches that have to be managed and applied. By removing unnecessary packages, you also reduce the number of potential vulnerabilities, thus making the resulting system more secure. Reducing the system's footprint also results in lower resource consumption and improved performance.

&jeos; is delivered as pre-configured and ready-to-run virtual machine images. The system comes with the jeos-firstboot wizard for configuring system locales and root password during the first boot. &jeos; ships with the SSH server enabled and excluded from the firewall configuration. The spplied Kiwi templates make it possible to create customized &jeos; images.

sect2.title: Usage of kernel-default-base
sect2.para: Because of size constraints, &jeos; images use the package kernel-default-base as the default kernel. This kernel does not contain drivers for bare metal. This allows for a much smaller footprint.

If your specific use case requires any of the omitted modules, you need to manually install the package kernel-default to get a full tree of the kernel modules, i.e the same kernel used by a regular SUSE Linux Enterprise Server installation.

sect3.title: No repository available by default
sect3.para: When installing a &sls; from the installation media, the system will automatically get the installation media as the default offline channel.
&sls; &jeos; has no channel by default, you need to register your system first, to access our Online Channels. Please refer to section Registering your system.

sect3.title: Zypper Configuration
sect3.para: &jeos; is a smaller form factor of &sls;. This means it has a smaller foot print but provides all the proper configurations and capabilities to be transformed into a full SUSE Linux Enterprise Server operating system. For achieving this smaller system, two configurations of zypper (/etc/zypp/zypp.conf) differ from the regular &sls; installation.

sect3.title: List of Base Packages
sect3.para: We are using a kiwi configuration file for generating our SUSE Linux Enterprise Server &jeos; images, and in this file we explicitly list packages that should be included in the images. We refer to these set of packages as "Base Packages".

important.title: Base Packages dependencies are not listed
important.para: Base packages will pull their dependency packages when the images will be created, thus the list of "Preinstalled packages" in the images will contains more packages than the "Base packages list".

important.title: Images started with qemu
important.para: In case you start an image directly with qemu-kvm on a SUSE Linux Enterprise Server 12 host, the virtual BIOS will not provide a system UUID. Such a UUID is used when registering systems with SUSEConnect. In case a system is registered without a UUID, it cannot be properly tracked and may not have access to all repositories. Therefore it is recommended to provide a UUID on the qemu-kvm command line:
